<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
9702/22  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 393, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 AS Level Structured Questions  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
February/March 2020  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[752, 325, 905, 340]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 560]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 603]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 60.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 106, 561, 144]]<|/det|>
\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 163, 526, 180]]<|/det|>
\[W = \rho \Delta V\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 195, 536, 225]]<|/det|>
\[\phi = -\frac{Gm}{r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 235, 524, 252]]<|/det|>
\[\rho = \rho gh\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 262, 561, 294]]<|/det|>
\[\rho = \frac{1}{3}\frac{Nm}{V}\langle c^2\rangle\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 305, 536, 320]]<|/det|>
\[a = -\omega^2 x\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 339, 615, 375]]<|/det|>
\[\nu = \nu_{0}\cos \omega t\] \[\nu = \pm \omega \sqrt{(\chi_{0}^{2} - \chi^{2})}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 380, 536, 415]]<|/det|>
\[f_{0} = \frac{f_{s}V}{\nu\pm\nu_{s}}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 425, 536, 460]]<|/det|>
\[V = \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 467, 628, 486]]<|/det|>
\[1 / C = 1 / C_{1} + 1 / C_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 500, 596, 519]]<|/det|>
\[C = C_{1} + C_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 529, 526, 556]]<|/det|>
\[W = \frac{1}{2} QV\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 570, 531, 588]]<|/det|>
\[I = A n v q\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 603, 596, 622]]<|/det|>
\[R = R_{1} + R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 637, 628, 655]]<|/det|>
\[1 / R = 1 / R_{1} + 1 / R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 668, 517, 702]]<|/det|>
\[V_{\mathrm{H}} = \frac{BI}{ntq}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 715, 561, 732]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\sin \omega t\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 747, 581, 766]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\exp (-\lambda t)\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 777, 536, 811]]<|/det|>
\[\lambda = \frac{0.693}{t_{\frac{1}{2}}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 685, 91]]<|/det|>
A dolphin is swimming under water at a constant speed of \(4.50 \text{m s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 146, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
The dolphin emits a sound as it swims directly towards a stationary submerged diver. The frequency of the sound heard by the diver is \(9560 \text{Hz}\). The speed of sound in the water is \(1510 \text{m s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 887, 181]]<|/det|>
Determine the frequency, to three significant figures, of the sound emitted by the dolphin.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 350, 920, 368]]<|/det|>
<form>frequency = .................................................... Hz [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 380, 146, 399]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 380, 920, 414]]<|/det|>
The dolphin strikes the bottom of a floating ball so that the ball rises vertically upwards from the surface of the water, as illustrated in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 420, 751, 580]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 594, 532, 613]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 625, 606, 644]]<|/det|>
The ball leaves the water surface with speed \(5.6 \text{m s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 657, 485, 675]]<|/det|>
Assume that air resistance is negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 688, 181, 707]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 688, 866, 705]]<|/det|>
Calculate the maximum height reached by the ball above the surface of the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[512, 874, 920, 892]]<|/det|>
<form>height = .................................................... m [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 72, 180, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 887, 89]]<|/det|>
The ball leaves the water at time \(t = 0\) and reaches its maximum height at time \(t = T\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 102, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 2.2, sketch a graph to show the variation of the speed of the ball with time \(t\) from \(t = 0\) to \(t = T\). Numerical values are **not** required.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[361, 144, 631, 311]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 329, 534, 346]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 344, 920, 362]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 376, 180, 395]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 376, 452, 395]]<|/det|>
The mass of the ball is \(0.45 \text{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 406, 920, 439]]<|/det|>
Use your answer in **(b)(i)** to calculate the change in gravitational potential energy of the ball as it rises from the surface of the water to its maximum height.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[242, 606, 920, 625]]<|/det|>
change in gravitational potential energy = .................................................... J [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 638, 180, 657]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 638, 920, 670]]<|/det|>
State and explain the variation in the magnitude of the acceleration of the ball as it falls back towards the surface of the water if air resistance is **not** negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[845, 810, 920, 828]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 841, 920, 858]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 71, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 443, 88]]<|/det|>
State what is meant by work done.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<form>........................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 138, 920, 158]]<|/det|>
<form>........................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 163, 920, 181]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 194, 146, 212]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 194, 895, 212]]<|/det|>
A skier is pulled along horizontal ground by a wire attached to a kite, as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[272, 220, 724, 348]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 373, 591, 392]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 405, 920, 438]]<|/det|>
The skier moves in a straight line along the ground with a constant speed of \(4.4 \text{m s}^{-1}\). The wire is at an angle of \(30^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. The tension in the wire is \(140 \text{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 452, 181, 470]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 451, 809, 470]]<|/det|>
Calculate the work done by the tension to move the skier for a time of 30 s.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[477, 605, 920, 623]]<|/det|>
<form>work done = ....................................................... J [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 636, 181, 655]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 636, 920, 685]]<|/det|>
The weight of the skier is \(860\mathrm{N}.\) The vertical component of the tension in the wire and the weight of the skier combine so that the skier exerts a downward pressure on the ground of \(2400\mathrm{Pa}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 698, 707, 715]]<|/det|>
Determine the total area of the skis in contact with the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[524, 884, 920, 902]]<|/det|>
<form>area = .................................................... $\text{m}^2$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[895, 884, 920, 902]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 72, 180, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 70, 831, 89]]<|/det|>
The wire attached to the kite is uniform. The stress in the wire is \(9.6 \times 10^{6} \text{Pa}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 101, 479, 120]]<|/det|>
Calculate the diameter of the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[492, 240, 920, 260]]<|/det|>
<form>diameter = .................................................... m [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 272, 146, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 272, 845, 291]]<|/det|>
The variation with extension \(x\) of the tension \(F\) in the wire in **(b)** is shown in Fig. 3.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 300, 747, 551]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[462, 570, 534, 588]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 600, 715, 620]]<|/det|>
A gust of wind increases the tension in the wire from 140 N to 210 N.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 631, 648, 650]]<|/det|>
Calculate the change in the strain energy stored in the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[371, 817, 920, 836]]<|/det|>
<form>change in strain energy = ................................................. J [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 848, 920, 867]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 12]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 71, 836, 88]]<|/det|>
Calculate the separation \(d\) between the centres of adjacent slits of the grating.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 256, 920, 275]]<|/det|>
<form>d = .................................................... m [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 288, 180, 306]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 288, 608, 306]]<|/det|>
The red laser light is replaced with blue laser light.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 319, 920, 352]]<|/det|>
State and explain the change, if any, to the angle between the third order diffraction maxima.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[845, 446, 920, 465]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 457, 920, 476]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Another battery Q of e.m.f. \(1.2 \text{V}\) and negligible internal resistance is now connected into the circuit of Fig. 5.1 to produce the new circuit shown in Fig. 5.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[354, 106, 641, 288]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 306, 534, 324]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 5.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 336, 920, 370]]<|/det|>
State whether the addition of battery Q causes the current to decrease, increase or remain the same in:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 381, 180, 400]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 380, 920, 399]]<|/det|>
resistor X ......................................................................................................... [1]

battery P. ......................................................................................................... [1]

The circuit shown in Fig. 5.2 is modified to produce the new circuit shown in Fig. 5.3.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[356, 462, 641, 612]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 660, 243, 678]]<|/det|>
Calculate:

<label>(i)</label>

the total resistance of the two resistors connected in parallel

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[479, 763, 920, 782]]<|/det|>
<form>resistance = ....................................................... $\Omega$

the current in resistor Y.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[505, 868, 920, 886]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A uniform electric field is produced between two parallel metal plates. The electric field strength is \(1.4 \times 10^{4} \text{N} \text{C}^{-1}\). The potential difference between the plates is \(350 \text{V}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 117, 146, 136]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 470, 136]]<|/det|>
Calculate the separation of the plates.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[479, 225, 920, 245]]<|/det|>
<form>separation = .................................................... m [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 256, 146, 274]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 255, 920, 291]]<|/det|>
A nucleus of mass \(8.3 \times 10^{-27} \text{kg}\) is now placed in the electric field. The electric force acting on the nucleus is \(6.7 \times 10^{-15} \text{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 303, 183, 322]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 303, 890, 323]]<|/det|>
Calculate the charge on the nucleus in terms of \(e\), where \(e\) is the elementary charge.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[505, 458, 920, 477]]<|/det|>
<form>charge = .................................................... $e$ [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 489, 181, 508]]<|/det|>
